dt: {bc}to express warning or disapproval to especially in a gentle, earnest, or {d_link|solicitous|solicitous} manner
{bc}to give friendly earnest advice or encouragement to

dt.t: … users are {wi}admonished{/wi} to change passwords regularly …

dt: {bc}to say (something) as advice or a warning

dt.t: {ldquo}Please be silent while I tell my story,{rdquo} LaPautre {wi}admonished{/wi}.

pt: {sc}reprove{/sc} {sc}rebuke{/sc} {sc}reprimand{/sc} {sc}admonish{/sc} {sc}reproach{/sc} {sc}chide{/sc} mean to criticize adversely. {sc}reprove{/sc} implies an often kindly intent to correct a fault.
{sc}rebuke{/sc} suggests a sharp or stern reproof.
{sc}reprimand{/sc} implies a severe, formal, often public or official rebuke.
{sc}admonish{/sc} suggests earnest or friendly warning and counsel.

pt.t: {it}admonished{/it} by my parents to control expenses

pt: {sc}reproach{/sc} and {sc}chide{/sc} suggest displeasure or disappointment expressed in mild reproof or scolding.

quotes.t: He is sympathetic but never condescending, or patronizing, or moralizing. His purpose is not to {qword}admonish{/qword} or deplore but to understand.
Cops are, from the first day in the academy, {qword}admonished{/qword} that juveniles must not be shot unless in dire emergency …
"You landed in back of him," said Paul, my guide and friend. As he {qword}admonished{/qword} me, the fish turned obligingly, opened its mouth, wide and white, and engulfed my fly.

et: Middle English {it}amonysshen, admonisshen, amonescen,{/it} alteration (with assimilation to the verbal suffix {it}-issh, -esce,{/it} borrowed from Anglo-French {it}-iss-,{/it} going back to the Latin inceptive suffix {it}-ēsc-, -īsc-{/it}) of {it}amonesten,{/it} borrowed from Anglo-French {it}amonester,{/it} going back to Vulgar Latin {it}*admonestāre,{/it} probably derivative of {it}*admonestus,{/it} past participle of Latin {it}admonēre{/it} "to give a reminder to, give advice to, caution" (modeled on {it}comestus,{/it} past participle of {it}comedere{/it} "to eat up, consume") from {it}ad-{/it} {et_link|ad-|ad-} + {it}monēre{/it} "to bring to the notice of, give warning" {ma}{mat|mind:1|}{/ma}

The source of {it}*admonestāre{/it} is uncertain. A cross between {it}admonēre{/it} and {it}molestāre,{/it} "to disturb, annoy, worry," has been hypothesized, though the lack of any Romance progeny for {it}molestus, molestāre,{/it} etc., militates against the presence of this verb in proto-Romance.
shortdef: to indicate duties or obligations to
to express warning or disapproval to especially in a gentle, earnest, or solicitous manner
to give friendly earnest advice or encouragement to
